TestDescription.Description:
[p]One of the scans performed by Acunetix WVS has generated an Host Header Attack Alert. The scan made a password reset request with a custom Host header. When the user clicked on the reset link the AcuMonitor Service captured this request and issued this alert.[/p]
In many cases, developers are trusting the HTTP Host header value and using it to generate links, import scripts and even generate password resets links with its value. This is a very bad idea, because the HTTP Host header can be controlled by an attacker. This can be exploited using web-cache poisoning and by abusing alternative channels like password reset emails.
TestDescription.Impact: An attacker can manipulate the Host header as seen by the web application and cause the application to behave in unexpected ways.
TestDescription.Recommendation: The web application should use the SERVER_NAME instead of the Host header. It should also create a dummy vhost that catches all requests with unrecognized Host headers. This can also be done under Nginx by specifying a non-wildcard SERVER_NAME, and under Apache by using a non-wildcard serverName and turning the UseCanonicalName directive on. Consult references for detailed information.

Reference.database: Automated Detection of Host Header Attacks
